newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - Feb 12.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - Feb 12.

text.p: The New York Times reported the following business stories on Wednesday:

* China has indicated it is willing to end some of its largest trade barriers, including some protecting state- and military-operated industries from foreign competition, in exchange for membership in the World Trade Organisation.

* Chevron's $700 million investment on the Tengiz oil fields of Kazakstan is paying off. The company is expected to tell analysts Wednesday that it made more than $80 million last year from the project.

* The number of U.S. companies expressing worry over the dollar's rise has been surprisingly small. Officials at Boeing, General Electric and Intel recently have dismissed worries about the currency's rise.

* As big banks and giant credit companies get involved in the business of sub-prime lending, competitive pressures are exposing cracks in the industry that have sent companies such as Mercury Finance and Jayhawk Acceptance reeling.
* Time Warner said it was determined to improve cash flow and pay off its $18 billion in debt after reporting fourth-quarter net income of $59 million, or a loss of $0.03 a share.
* Stocks rebounded, and the Dow industrials closed up 51.57 points at 6,858.11.
* The yield on the 30-year bond was unchanged at 6.70 percent.
* A strike by the pilots of AMR's American Airlines could inconvenience not only travelers on American Airlines, but also those on other carriers as the holiday weekend approaches.
* A White House commission plans to release a report Wednesday that seeks to cut the rate of airline accidents by 80 percent.
* Worker productivity outside the farm sector grew at 2.2 percent in the fourth quarter, the fastest rate in three years.
* Westinghouse posted a $34 million fourth-quarter loss as an operating loss at CBS offset better results at the company's local television and radio stations.
* Centennial Technologies dismissed its chairman, Emanuel Pinez, and began an investigation into its financial statements.
* VF Corp said it would combine its 17 businesses into five as part of restructuring to cut $150 million a year in costs.
* Candymaker Mars Inc plans to recruit a black actor for its advertising in selling the 3 Musketeers candy bar.
